The future is here 🥳!

Follow up to https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/623.

title: Upgrade `heck` to `0.4.0`
body: Dependabot wasn't able to do it on its own.

title: Use `Mapping` in `trait-erc20` Example
body:
Looks like I forgot a contract. This is basically just a copy-pasta of our updated
`ERC-20` example.

title: Update ERC-20 and ERC-721 UI Tests
body:
This PR updates the UI tests which compile example `ERC-20` and `ERC-721` contracts to
match our latests examples, which use `Mapping`.

title: Use compile time checks for `blake2` hashes
body:
This supersedes #1072, which updates the `blake2` crate from `v0.9` to `v0.10`. While
resolving some of the conflicts I realized that we could have some of the
variable-sized hashing checks at compile time instead of at runtime. Figured it would be
good to get more eyes on this than having it lost in a `dependabot` PR.

title: Streamline terminology to "instantiation" (instead of "deployment")
body:
Needed for https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/690.

There are some more mentions regarding "deploy", but those are in dev comments regarding the `fn deploy()`, hence I've left them as is.

title: Port multisig example to low level data structures
body:
This removes all usages of data structures in `collections`. The new code shows some pain points of ink! and the pallet-contracts when removing those collections. I think this is exactly the reason why we should port this example with sub optimal code: We can come back, iterate and observe the improvements.

These are some pain point of the contract which could be fixed but would change the interface so I did leave them as is:

1. Owners are stored in a packed `Vec`. The complexity of adding and removing owners scales linearly with the amount of owners. We might need to cap them.
2. The transactions id are generated from a monotonic counter which will run out if ids eventually. I don't think this will be an issue in practice but we might want to either provide a "defrag" function or let the user pass in the id. I would prefer the latter but it will change the interface.

It also shows some shortcomings of the pallet-contracts map interface. I think we want the following functionality to paller-contracts:
1. When setting a key in a mapping we want to return whether this key already existed
2. Check for existence without reading the value
3. Allow to get and remove and the same time (`take`)

title: Fix nightly clippy errors
body:
The `master` CI is currently failing because of this (and because of our incompatible `master` with the UI's).

It's a pity that `ink-waterfall` currently does not work due to the UI's, I would be very interested in seeing the gas/size changes. Let's wait with the merge until we have the UI compatible again.

title: Do not include `libsecp256k1` on Windows
body:
Fixes the broken `cargo-contract` Windows CI. See https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/1068 for more details.

CI fails due to expected incompatible ink! with `substrate-contracts-node` since the deposit PR merge.

title: Add Windows and Mac CI stages
body:
Follow-up to https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/1066.

The runs take quite long, I've enabled them only `master` for now.

title: Revert "Switch from `libsecp256k1` to `secp256k1` (#1052)"
body:
This reverts part of the commit 78b45330e453500a759a2b53b7ab6f16bfb91caa.

We found that ink! contracts can no longer be compiled on MacOs due to https://github.com/rust-bitcoin/rust-secp256k1/pull/254. So this PR makes the Wasm-compiled code of `eth_compatibility` still use `libsecp256k1`.

title: Allow specifying `payable` constructors
body:
Before this change ink! constructors were payable by default. This was because all
contracts were required to place an endowment in order to stay alive.

However, with the changes introduced in https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/10082 this is no
longer necessary. Instead we can allow users to specify whether or not they want their
constructors to be `payable`.

We'll need to wait for the Substrate PR to get merged before merging this one. This is
because if we deploy a contract without also initializing it with some value we get a
`NewContractNotFunded` error.

Closes https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/1027.

P.S, we'll also want to change `endowment` to `value` to be consistent with
`pallet-contracts`, but that can be done in a follow-up PR.

title: Rename `EcdsaRecover` ➔ `EcdsaRecovery`
body: @ascjones I'm also thinking about if we should rename `ink_env::ecdsa_recover(…)` to something like `ink_env::ecdsa_recovery(…)` or `ink_env::recover_ecdsa(…)`. What does the native speaker say?

title: Name API consistently: `transferred_balance` ➔ `transferred_value`
body:
I honestly don't care what we rename it to, *but we should finally make the naming consistent*. 

I'm not opening up the whole thing with renaming endowment to value that was started in https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/10082 here.

title: Remove `BelowSubsistenceThreshold` and `NewContractNotFunded`

labels.description: The issue or PR is currently on ice and not further discussed or developed.

body:
Do not merge yet!

Closes https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/1044.

Follow-up to https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/10082.

I haven't adapted the off-chain testing environment for the deposit mechanism, I'll create a follow-up for that. Right now, the off-chain env doesn't take the new deposit mechanism into account in any way.

title: Move linting checks to start of CI run
body:
It's really annoying to wait half an hour while the CI does its job, only to realize that
you forgot to run `rustfmt` and now you have to wait another half an hour for the CI to
pass.

This PR moves our linting steps to the beginning of the CI pipeline so that these
failures can be caught and addressed quickly.

This PR also allows the CI build to continue despite the lint steps failing. This is
useful if you care about a step later in the CI pipeline (e.g contract sizes) but don't
necessarily care if your code is formatted properly.

title: Upgrade `seal0` calls to `seal1`
body:
Closes https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/879.

Uses the `seal1` API from https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/blob/master/frame/contracts/src/wasm/runtime.rs.

The only thing that changed is no longer passing the `len` for some of the pointers.

However it appears to reduce the amount of increase of each additional type of topic (see example below), since the extracted non generic part will not be duplicated each time. e.g. commenting out the `Option<AccountId>` topics

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/75586/142614944-8700512b-ce55-4686-a164-1b198bf8dba7.png)

title: Specify minor version for `parity-scale-codec` in TOML files
body:
I just spent some time trying to figure out why my UI tests were failing locally but
passing on the CI. I realized that it was because my local repo was using
`parity-scale-codec` `v2.1.1`. This was totally file as far as Cargo was concerned since
we only specified `2` in our TOML files. However, for our test this was not fine, and
`v2.3.1` was required. Since `ink!` doesn't have a Lockfile I figured I'd manually bump
the required version ([`cargo-upgrade`](https://github.com/killercup/cargo-edit#cargo-upgrade) made this a breeze FYI).

title: Bump `trybuild` and adapt test fixtures
body: Fixing the broken `master` CI.

title: Remove unknown lint
body:
The `if_then_panic` lint has been moved to the linting level `pedantic`: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/commit/d8fcfd7d64f102402819aba3ac91954a7a6888cc.

We currently use the default linting level, thus the `clippy` CI currently fails with `unknown lint`.

I'm force-merging this PR to fix the broken `master` CI.

title: Fix ink! message result return reverts
Follow-up: SpreadLayout
body:
Implements
- https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/993
- https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/992

Partially implements
- https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/988

Note: Only partial since fallible ink! constructors remain artificially forbidden as of now. Another follow-up PR might change that soon.

Doesn't implement, but related
- https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/991

All in all this heavily simplifies working with the new `SpreadLayout` traits in ink! smart contracts. As a consequence we can further simplify https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/979 after merging this PR.

title: Add some detail to the release notes about the metadata versioning
Simple Mapping type improvements
body:
Based on @HCastano 's https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/946 PR.

This fork of the above PR improves the `Mapping` type even further which reduces the ERC-20 example smart contract Wasm file size to 10.8kB so far.

# Implementation Notes

- The ink! codegen does not automatically generate `SpreadAllocate` implementations of its `#[ink(storage)]` struct and at this point it is even undecided if that's a good idea. Therefore we currently are required to implement `SpreadAllocate` manually in the ERC-20 example contract.
- The ERC-20 `new` constructor as well as the `new_init` method seem a bit verbose but we are working on some improvements to make this less of a deal.
- The `EncodeLike` trait usage in the `Mapping` type allows us to use `&(&K1, &K2)` in the `Mapping::{get, insert}` methods instead of just `&(K1, K2)` which saves us a lot of Wasm file size overhead with respect to big value types such as `Balance` and especially `AccountId`.
- To avoid dealing with big value types helper methods have been implemented in the ERC-20 example contract such as `allowance_impl` and `balance_of_impl` that take and forward their arguments by reference instead of by value.

title: Add SpreadAllocate and PackedAllocate traits and impls
body: Implements https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/961.

title: Use edition 2021
body: Upgrade was trivial. Just a few doc tests in `ink_storage` had to be upgraded.

title: Always revert state upon encountering Result::Err
body:
This fixes some misconception between ink! and SEAL.

Brought up by @xgreenx in this comment first: https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/641#issuecomment-947821442

title: Optimize get property for most primitive types
body:
Implements https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/972.

The main trick in this PR is that we "trust" SEAL in that it delivers correct inputs to ink! result buffers for functions like `seal_caller`.
Before this PR we additionally "checked" the given values by decoding them. Now we simply take their bit patterns directly.

This has turned many of the property functions into infallible functions.

## Benchmarks

- ERC-1155: 49.3 kB -> 49.1 kB
- Trait-ERC-20: 29.3kB -> 29.1kB

Savings are not huge but go into the right direction.

title: Base Key on [u8; 32]
body:
Implements https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/950.

This change removes lots of APIs from `Key` type that may result in inefficient computation.
This required some changes in the rest of the ink! codebase.
Unfortunately this PR slightly pessimizes Wasm file sizes.
For example the ERC-20 contract Wasm file size is 29.4kB without this change and 29.5kB with this change.

Even through the pessimization with respect to Wasm file sizes I believe that this change will allow other optimizations.

This PR is best reviewed commit by commit.

body:
As pointed out by @justin-parity in our public channel.

[Preview here](https://github.com/paritytech/ink/blob/cmichi-add-compatibility-note-rc6/RELEASES.md).

This is required to fix the failing `cargo-contract` CI (specifically the Windows run).

We are currently using a way outdated version of `libsecp256k1`, upgrading it turned out harder than just switching to the other `no_std` compatible crate.

Otherwise crates.io refrains from publishing:

```
invalid upload request: invalid length 6, expected at most 5 keywords per crate
```

This PR contains two things:
* Rename `multisig_plain` to just `multisig`.
* Allow transactions which are submitted and evaluated via `eval_transaction` to be payable. This is something we fixed a while ago for `invoke_transaction`, but apparently forgot for the eval function. I'll add an `ink-waterfall` test for `eval_transaction` with a payable transaction as a follow-up.

Fix or silence some more clippy warnings
Fix a clippy warning
body: The `clippy` warning prevents our CI from building a new container ...

title: Fix nightly clippy errors
body: Fixes the broken `master`.

title: Implement selector_id!, selector_bytes! and blake2x256! macros
body:
Inspired by the METIS library utility macros this PR adds those macros (different implementation and API) to ink! as built-ins.

Link: https://github.com/patractlabs/metis/blob/main/crates/lang/macro/src/lib.rs

Adds the following proc. macros to `ink_lang_macro` crate that are exposed from `ink_lang`:

- `selector_id!`: Takes a string or byte string literal as input and computes the selector ID of type `u32`.
- `selector_bytes!`: Takes a string or byte string literal as input and computes the selector bytes of type `[u8; 4]`.
- `blake2x256!`: Takes a string or byte string literal as input and computes the BLAKE2b 256-bit hash of type `[u8; 32]`.

# ToDo List

- [x] Write UI tests for ...
    - [x] `selector_id!`
    - [x] `selector_bytes!`
    - [x] `blake2x256!`

title: Simple Mapping Storage Primitive
body:
An implementation of what's described in https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/945.

~~Some things I'm still unsure about:~~

~~1. The handling of `Mapping`'s `key` field
Not sure if this should be user initialized since it's kinda an implementation detail
which is there to make sure we don't have any collisions in storage.~~

~~2. The `SpreadLayout` implementation
So from what I can tell, when we implement this trait we're supposed to indicate how our
structure should be represented in the contract storage.  In the case of `Mapping`, since
it doesn't actually own any data, its really just a proxy for how we represent `Key` in
storage. Am I thinking about this correctly?~~

title: Update pretty_assertions requirement from 0.7.1 to 1.0.0

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
Updates the requirements on [pretty_assertions](https://github.com/colin-kiegel/rust-pretty-assertions) to permit the latest version.
Release notes

Sourced from pretty_assertions's releases.

v1.0.0

Note: As pretty_assertions has in practice had a stable API for several years, this feature release takes the opportunity to increment the version to 1.0.0 instead of 0.8.0. No breaking changes are expected.

Removed

  • assert_ne no longer warns if values match using PartialEq but not with Debug. This was noted as no longer being necessary after Rust 1.25 (current MSRV 1.35.0)

Added

  • Officially support no_std (thanks to @​Luro02 for the report and reviews!). Adds the std and alloc features to the pretty_assertions crate, with std enabled by default (#83, @​tommilligan)
  • Adds the unstable feature to the pretty_assertions crate, for use with nightly rustc (#81, @​tommilligan)
  • Add a drop in replacement for the unstable stdlib assert_matches macro, behind the unstable flag - thanks @​gilescope for the suggestion! (#81, @​tommilligan)
Changelog

Sourced from pretty_assertions's changelog.

v1.0.0

Removed

  • assert_ne no longer warns if values match using PartialEq but not with Debug. This was noted as no longer being necessary after Rust 1.25 (current MSRV 1.35.0)

Added

  • Officially support no_std (thanks to @​Luro02 for the report and reviews!). Adds the std and alloc features to the pretty_assertions crate, with std enabled by default (#83, @​tommilligan)
  • Adds the unstable feature to the pretty_assertions crate, for use with nightly rustc (#81, @​tommilligan)
  • Add a drop in replacement for the unstable stdlib assert_matches macro, behind the unstable flag - thanks @​gilescope for the suggestion! (#81, @​tommilligan)

v0.7.2

  • Fix macro hygiene for expansion in a no_implicit_prelude context (#70, @​tommilligan)

v0.7.1

  • Fix a bug where multiline changes showed an unhelpful inline diff (#66, @​tommilligan)

v0.7.0

Changed

  • Move from difference to diff for calculating diffs. The exact assertion messages generated may differ from previous versions. (#52, @​tommilligan)

For example, the following assertion message from v0.7.0:

Was previously rendered like this in v0.6.1:

Added

  • Support for unsized values (#42, @​stanislav-tkach)
  • Document the Comparison struct, which was previously hidden. This can be used to generate a pretty diff of two values without panicking. (#52, @​tommilligan)

Fixed

  • Fix some unhygenic macro expansions (#41, @​tommilligan)

Internal

  • Test Windows targets in CI (#46, @​tommilligan)
  • Bump ansi_term version to 0.12 (#34, @​waywardmonkeys)
  • Code health improvements (#34, @​waywardmonkeys)
Commits
  • 737c861 Merge pull request #83 from tommilligan/assert-eq-no-std
  • 659b66b chore: prepare for v1.0.0 release
  • 0a32464 feat: fix and test for no_std with alloc

title: CI: remove gcda files from cache
body: To address this kind of behavior https://gitlab.parity.io/parity/ink/-/jobs/1144704#L1789 when `.gcda` profiling files remain in the cache from the previous job.

title: [storage] Allow one variant enum to derive SpreadLayout
Minor simplifications and code dupe reductions in codegen
body: Carved out work from #665.

title: Fix `env::block_timestamp` example
body:
I noticed that the example contains a mistake. The comment says
```
/// The function can be executed at most once every 100 blocks.
```
But the `env` function used there is actually `block_timestamp()`.

I first thought about just modifying the comment to 
```
/// The function can be executed at most once every 100 milliseconds.
```
But since we don't know if the environment `Timestamp` actually counts in milliseconds we can't do that.

title: Improve macro hygiene in message and constructor selector namespace types
body: Carved out of #665 .

title: Misc cleanups in ink! codegen
body:
Work carved out of https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/665 in an attempt to make its diff more manageable.

- Some macro hygiene improvements.
- Modernization of some codegen parts.
- Simplification of codegen parts.

title: Move ink_lang_macro UI tests into macro-specific folders
body: Carved out refactoring work from https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/665 to shrink its diff.

title: Refactor and modernize dispatch codegen
body:
Work carved out of https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/665.

- Improves macro hygiene of dispatch codegen.
- Modernizes generated selector namespaces of ink! messages and ink! constructors.
    - Uses const generic parameters instead of abusing array lengths.
- Improves panic messages for debugging dispatching.
- Uses big-letter hex-encoded IDs for generated message and constructor info types.

title: Add trait-incrementer example smart contract
body: New example ink! smart contract extracted from https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/665.

title: Check namespace argument is identifier
body: Just checks that `argument` in `#[ink(namespace = "argument")]` is a valid Rust identifier and adds tests for it.

title: Unrestrict parity-scale-codec crate version
body: Just use any version `2`. Micro PR.

title: Fix script which triggers downstream pipelines
body:
The reason why the `ink-waterfall` yesterday mistakenly displayed a successful run for the `scale-info` PR is that the script currently exits with 0 after the timeout. So the script timed out and exited with 0, marking the CI stage as success.

This PR fixes this behavior and increases the timeout from the previous 30 mins to 1h.

title: Make #[ink(selector = ..)] take a u32 parameter instead of a string
body:
This PR is the result of work in https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/665.

Currently ink! requires a user to input a string parameter for a message or constructor selector like the following:
```
#[ink(selector = "0xC0DECAFE")]
```
This is not necessary and the implementation requires the huge `regex` crate that bloats the compilation times.
The PR changes the `selector` property to take a `u32` integer instead. This allows for inputs like the following:
```
#[ink(selector = C0DECAFE)]
#[ink(selector = 1)]
```
README, example contracts and tests are updated as well.

title: Expand selectors as hex-encoded literals in metadata
body:
Extracted from work in done in https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/665.

Using the utilities provided in this PR we can also use hex-encoded literals elsewhere in our macro expansion.

title: Improve SpreadLayout and StorageLayout derive macro hygiene
body: PR and side-work resulting from my work on https://github.com/paritytech/ink/pull/665/commits.

title: Changed the field `name` to `label`
body:
Updated the code generation of ABI. Instead of "name" in messages, constructors, arguments, events we are using "label".
Changed the behavior of "label" for messages and constructors, now it is a string instead of an array. 
For trait's messages, we will use the "TRAIT_IDENT::MESSAGE_IDENT" format of representation.

This PR is related to https://github.com/paritytech/ink/issues/900.

title: CI: chown the built docs
body:
Closes: https://github.com/paritytech/ci_cd/issues/200
cc https://github.com/paritytech/ci_cd/issues/92

title: CI: thou shall use vault secrets
Fix code coverage
body:
We need to link dead code for the code coverage. This is because the code coverage must take dead code into account ‒ it's dead code which should actually be tested in some way; if it's not tested it's not covered and this should show up negatively in our coverage results.

For trait cross-calls we have a special case though, which I've described in the code comment of this PR, so for brevity I won't restate it here.

Another way of implementing this would be to place an early return in the methods which insert `__ink_enforce_error` in [`cross_calling.rs`](https://github.com/paritytech/ink/blob/master/crates/lang/codegen/src/generator/cross_calling.rs) (in case `INK_COVERAGE_REPORTING` is set to `true`). I've decided against this, since those code paths would then be excluded for all tests which are run in our `codecov` CI stage, making it impossible to improve coverage for them.

title: Implemented ECDSA recover function.
body:
Added support of `seal_ecdsa_recover` from the https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/pull/9686.
This function allows to recover the ecdsa compressed public key from the signature and message hash. It will return `ECDSAPublicKey` which has two methods `to_eth_address` and `to_account_id`.
